snippet: Teenagers will now be able to post items that can be seen by the public, making it easier for the social network to turn a post into an ad that can be shown widely.
abstract: Facebook loosens its privacy rules for teenagers as debate swirls over online threats to children from bullies and sexual predators; moves allows teenagers to post status updates, videos and images that can be seen by anyone, not just friends and friends of friends; it will also make it easier for the social network to turn posts into advertisements that can be shown widely and generate revenue.

byline.contributor: Mark Scott contributed reporting from London.

lead_paragraph: Teenagers will now be able to post items that can be seen by the public, making it easier for the social network to turn a post into an ad that can be shown widely.

headline.main: Facebook Eases Privacy Rules for Teenagers
headline.print_headline: Facebook Eases Privacy Rules For Teenagers
